qas.question: How many official radio and television networks does the government of Somalia operate?

plausible_answers.text: Telecommunications, internet, radio, print, television and postal services in the nation are largely concentrated in the private sector.

qas.question: What communication does the public sector concentrate in?
When was the National Communications Act dismantled?

context: Communications in Somalia encompasses the communications services and capacity of Somalia. <b14_0>Telecommunications, internet, radio, print, television and postal services in the nation are largely concentrated in the <a1_0><a5_0><a6_0>private<a6_0/><a5_0/><a1_0/> sector.<b14_0/> Several of the telecom firms have begun expanding their activities abroad. The Federal government operates <a0_0><a7_0><b11_0>two<b11_0/><a7_0/><a0_0/> official radio and television networks, which exist alongside a number of private and foreign stations. <a2_0><a8_0>Print media<a8_0/><a2_0/> in the country is also progressively giving way to news <a9_0>radio stations and online portals<a9_0/>, as <b13_0>internet connectivity and access<b13_0/> increases. Additionally, the national postal service is slated to be officially relaunched in <a3_0><a10_0><b12_0>2013<b12_0/><a10_0/><a3_0/> after a long absence. In <b15_0>2012<b15_0/>, a <a4_0>National Communications Act<a4_0/> was also approved by Cabinet members, which lays the foundation for the establishment of a National Communications regulator in the broadcasting and telecommunications sectors.
